children: A 73-year-old woman is evaluated for diminished vision in her right eye. The patient has a history compatible with previously undiagnosed and untreated giant cell arteritis.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is optic disc atrophy, which is characterized by pallor and flatness of the optic disc. Optic disc atrophy results from damage to the nerve fiber layer of the retina, optic nerve, optic chiasm, or optic tracts. . In younger patients, the most common cause of optic nerve atrophy is optic neuritis; in older patients, ischemic optic neuropathy is the most common etiology. This older patient with a history compatible with previously undiagnosed and untreated giant cell arteritis most likely has ischemic optic atrophy.
